title: 109_hr1245
content: The Act may be cited as the "Gynecologic Cancer Education and Awareness Act of 2005" or "Johanna's Law." It amends the Public Health Service Act. Section 317P of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include "Johanna's Law," which mandates a national public awareness campaign to educate healthcare providers and women about gynecologic cancers through written materials and public service announcements. The national campaign for gynecologic cancer awareness includes public service announcements in telecommunications media to encourage discussions with physicians about risks. Announcements provide information on obtaining written materials, early warning signs, and risk factors. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 6 months of the enactment of this subsection. The report to Congress includes past and present activities of the Department of Health and Human Services to increase awareness of different types of cancer, including gynecologic cancers, among the public and healthcare providers. It also includes descriptions of specific activities for each type of cancer awareness. The report to Congress details the funding and history of activities aimed at increasing awareness of various types of cancer, including gynecologic cancers. It includes goals, communication objectives, agency responsibilities, and expected outcomes of these activities. The curr_chunk discusses the duration of activities, outcomes observed, and evaluation methods used. It requires a description of results, analyses, and conclusions for each outcome or evaluation method. The Secretary must develop and submit a strategy to Congress for increasing awareness of different types of cancer, including gynecological cancers, consulting with private sector groups. By March 1, 2008, full compliance with all provisions of this section must be ensured. The Secretary must ensure that all provisions related to activities by the CDC and FDA are fully implemented and complied with. A report certifying compliance must be submitted to Congress by April 30, 2008. Failure to submit the certification will require the Secretary to provide explanations every 3 months. The Secretary must provide a detailed description of actions taken to comply with provisions related to CDC and FDA activities by a specified date. $16,500,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2007-2009 to carry out these requirements.
